Award.AwardTitle: Scholars Award: Observables in Hamiltonian Dynamics

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a technical project in the philosophy of physics. The PI, who has a PhD in both Physics and History and Philosophy of Science, will address an issue in the philosophical foundations of the General Theory of Relativity concerning the equivalence of two formulations of the theory. One tends to be preferred because it is much closer to how quantum mechanics is standardly formulated, which is better for the purposes of finding a viable theory of quantum gravity. However, that formulation seems to imply that change is an illusion; observables (what the formulation designates as real physical quantities) do not change with time. The other formulation of the theory is more in line with common sense; observables (within that formulation) do change with time. Nevertheless, this difference between the two formulations of the theory borders on the paradoxical; it is not clear what it means to say that they are equivalent. The PI proposes to resolve this tension by giving a novel and compelling argument for a new definition of observables that vary locally resolving the problem of time while maintaining the equivalence of the two formulations.  In addition to publishing the results of his research in three planned journal articles (and eventually in a book), the PI plans to make his work accessible to a wide audience through a series of six public lectures and through his relevant teaching at Cambridge.

This project examines the equivalence of the Hamiltonian formulation of General Relativity with the Lagrangian formulation to resolve the problem of time. Hamiltonian General Relativity has been associated with a lack of change in physically real observables since the mid-1950s, whereas the more fundamental Lagrangian treatment (Einstein's equations), like common sense, exhibits changing observables. Many leading physicists have commented on this unacceptable situation, but for various reasons an adequate solution has not been found. Two new definitions of observables have been proposed, one by the PI and another by Pons, Salisbury, and Sundermeyer. The PI seeks to take the crucial next step, of taking the recently-proposed definition of observables and testing them, by studying whether they correctly render equivalent formulations of various theories equivalent in their observational content. The project will shed light on research programs in quantum gravity, exhibits the fruitfulness of interaction between General Relativity and particle physics, and shows the utility of integrated history and philosophy of science for current science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This STS Scholars Award supported a project aiming to understand and partly resolve a conceptual puzzle that arises when one tries to merge Einstein's General Relativity (his theory of gravity and space-time proposed in the 1910s) with quantum mechanics (an apparently all-embracing physical framework from the 1920s).  The conceptual puzzle in question is called the "problem of time."  Attempting to merge these two theories in the most natural way leads to an apparent absence of time and change. 

 

Intellectual Merit

This project aimed to distinguish which facets of the problem of time arise from two different sources and to correct those from one source.  One source is a formulation of General Relativity, the Hamiltonian formulation, which is especially suitable for merging with quantum mechanics, but is available for any physical theory quite apart from quantum mechanics and is useful for celestial mechanics.  Another potential source for aspects of the problem of time is the process of merging the Hamiltonian formulation of General Relativity with quantum mechanics ("quantization"), a process that uses some standard prescriptions that succeed with other theories.  Those aspects of the problem of time that arise from the Hamiltonian formulation can be isolated and, crucially, can be corrected by requiring mathematical equivalence between the Hamiltonian formulation and the original formulation in terms of 4-dimensional space-time geometry.

 

But aren't Hamiltonian formulations always already mathematically equivalent to the original formulations of the theories in question?  Most 20th century physical theories, including the theories for light, gravity, and electrons, actually cannot be treated in the traditional Hamiltonian formalism, so it was necessary in the 1930s/1950s to reinvent a generalized Hamiltonian formalism that would accommodate them.  This reinvention, while mathematically sound, eventually came to be accompanied by some innovative interpretations about what changes of description do or do not imply real differences and, relatedly, how physically observable quantities should relate to changes of description.  One view is that changes of description should not affect observable quantities at all:  they should be invariant.  This project defends a new view according to which some kinds of change of description (such as are associated with light) should not affect observable quantities at all, but the changes of description relevant to General Relativity, namely changes of labelling places and times, should affect observable quantities in a rule-governed way akin to language translation.  By analogy, an American saying "snow is white" and a German saying "Schnee ist weiss" are uttering sentences that sound different but are equivalent under translation, and that is good enough---gravity's observables are covariant, not invariant.  It is not required to find a shared thought between the English speaker and the German speaker in a Platonic realm of ideas (though perhaps one exists).  This new definition is motivated by the PI's previous work, which imposes the novel requirement that equivalent theory formulations have equivalent observables.  Applying this new definition to standard particle physics examples shows that "massive" theories of light and gravity (theories according to which the wave pulses in question travel at a frequency-dependent speed less that the so-called speed of light c) do in fact have invariant observables for light and merely covariant observables for gravity. 

 

A further wrinkle is that the usual mathematical way to change the description in General Relativity involves comparing different space-time points with the same labels in different coordinate systems, akin to 1am EST vs. 1am EDT.  Requiring that anything deemed observable be the same at different moments, though subtly entrenched in the usual definition of observables, in fact simply imposes the absence of change by fiat.  Hence the origin of the problem of missing change, at least apart from introducing quantum mechanics, is exposed.  The project yielded a secure classical foundation for Hamiltonian General Relativity and provided hints for how the merger with quantum mechanics ought to be achieved. 

 

The project produced a long paper that critically assessed the work on "observables" of Hamiltonian General Relativity founding father Peter Bergmann, a paper that showed that the PI's bifurcated definition of observables leads to reasonable results when one combines light and gravity despite their different treatments of observables under change of descriptions, and one that assesses observables when gravity and electrons are combined, yielding plausible results. 

 

Broader Impact

The broader impact of this project includes showing the fruitfulness of relating often unrelated or rival branches of theoretical physics (namely General Relativity and particle physics), the surprising usefulness of the history and philosophy of science for resolving conceptual-technical problems in current physics, and the surprising intelligibility of General Relativity in comparison to some popular portraits.

 

The project affected the training of physics graduate students of one of the co-PIs at the University of Cologne and graduate students in mathematics and physics at the University of Cambridge.
